questions.question: A young sexually active man presented with multiple polypoid growths over his penis. Histopathological image of an excised lesion is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The histopathological image of the excised lesion is consistent with condyloma acuminata, which is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).

questions.question: All of the following are true regarding Bowen's disease except:

options.B: Marked dysplasia and hyperproliferative epidermis are seen
options.D: Virtually never develops into an invasive carcinoma

questions.explanation: Bowen's disease starts as a premalignant lesion and transforms into infiltrating squamous cellcarcinoma in approximately 10% of patients, usually over a span of many years.Bowen's disease occurs in the genital region of both men and women, usually in those older thanage 35 years. These lesions have a strong association with infection by high-risk humanpapillomavirus (HPV), most commonly type 16.Grossly, it appears as a solitary, thickened, gray-white, and opaque plaque.The below histological image of Bowen's disease shows dysplastic cells with large hyperchromaticnuclei, koilocytic atypia and an intact basement membrane.Bowen Disease - Histopathology889Bowen Disease - HistopathologyPremalignant lesions of invasive penile SCC:•Erythroplasia of Queyrat•Condyloma acuminatumKoilocytic atypiaDysplastic cells with largehyperchromatic nuclei⚫ Bowen's disease•Bowenoid papulosis occurs in young, sexually active adults. It presents as multiple reddish-brownpapular lesions and it is histologically indistinguishable from Bowen's disease, but virtually neverdevelops into invasive carcinoma.

questions.question: 879The biopsy of a resected inguinal mass from a patient shows marked fibrotic changes withprominent Leydig cells and hypoplastic Sertoli cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.B: CryptorchidismBowen diseased) Torsion testisQuestion 4:Testicular atrophy is not seen in which of the following conditions?a) A 25-year-old man with karyotype XXYb) A 45-year-old man with liver cirrhosis

questions.explanation: The given histopathological features are strongly suggestive of cryptorchidism.Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following:• Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development,marked hyalinization•Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis• Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells.Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac. It isthe most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrestanywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.•Phases of testicular descent:Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis. This phase of descentis regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.•• Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac. Thisphase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the890genitofemoral nerve.The exact pathogenesis remains unknown, however, deficiency in gonadotropins andMullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta arethought to play a role. It is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result insterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3-5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma).

questions.question: A 30-year-old man undergoes testicular biopsy as part of infertility work-up. Sperm countshows oligospermia. Microscopy shows only Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubules. What isthe most likely finding seen in the condition?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario depicts that the patient is having Sertoli cell-only syndrome, andpatients with this syndrome will have increased levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).The below image shows normal histology of testis:892Testis H&ELeydigcellsSertolicellsspermatogoniaprimary spermatocytessmooth musclespermatidsIn normal males, as spermatogenesis and testosterone production increase, the Sertoli cellsproduce inhibin, which inhibits the release of FSH. The Sertoli cells are supporting cells that areunder the action of FSH. Leydig cells, which are present in the interstitial spaces, are under theaction of luteinizing hormone(LH) and produce testosterone. Testosterone has a feedbackinhibition on LH.In Sertoli cell-only syndrome, within the seminiferous tubules, only Sertoli cells are seen and nogerm cells. Hence, there are no spermatozoa and there is no feedback inhibition, which results inincreased FSH levels. So, testosterone levels, and LH levels remain unaffected since Leydig cellsare not affected. Hence, the patient will have male secondary sexual characters.The most important indication of testicular biopsy is infertility workup.

questions.question: An 18-year-old boy presents with acute onset of testicular pain. On examination, the left testisis enlarged, tender and positioned higher than the right at an unusual angle. Pain is notrelieved on elevation of the scrotum. What histopathological changes can be seen in thiscondition?

options.A: Marked fibrosis with prominent Leydig cells and hypoplastic Sertoli cells
options.B: Dysplastic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, koilocytic atypia
options.D: Intense congestion, hemorrhage, and areas of infarction

questions.explanation: The most likely diagnosis is testicular torsion. The pathological changes range from intensecongestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction. In advanced stages, the testis ismarkedly enlarged and consists entirely of soft, necrotic, hemorrhagic tissue.893CM5Adult torsion is typically seen in adolescence and presents with the sudden onset of testicularpain. Neonatal torsion can occur either in utero or shortly after birth and the cause is unknown.It results from a bilateral anatomic defect that leads to increased mobility of the testes (bell-clapper abnormality). Twisting of the spermatic cord typically cuts off the venous drainage of thetestis. But, thick-walled arteries remain patent, producing intense vascular engorgement, followedby hemorrhagic infarction. If the testis is manually untwisted within approximately 6 hours of theonset of torsion, there is a good chance that the testis will remain viable.

questions.question: Which of the following infections primarily affects the testis?
questions.explanation: Syphilis and mumps affect the testis primarily and later spread to surrounding structures.894Syphilis can affect both the testis and epididymis, but invariably, the testis is involved first asgummas and diffuse interstitial inflammation.Mumps most commonly affects school-aged children, but testicular involvement is uncommon inthis age. Mumps infection in postpubertal males can lead to acute interstitial orchitis in 20 to30% of cases.Gonorrhea and tuberculosis affect the epididymis first, which can later spread to the testis.

questions.question: Which of the following testicular tumors is derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ?
questions.explanation: Germ-cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS) is a common precursor lesion of seminoma.Most testicular germ-cell tumors originate from a precursor lesion called GCNIS. It is believed toarise in utero and stay dormant until puberty, after which it may progress to seminoma ornon-seminomatous tumors.The exceptions to this rule are:•Prepubertal yolk-sac tumors• Teratomas• Adult spermatocyte tumorsThe lesion consists of atypical primordial germ cells, which have large nuclei and a clearcytoplasm and fail to develop into spermatogonia. This is because these cells retain the expressionof the transcription factors OCT3/4 and NANOG, which maintain the pluripotency of germ cellsand prevent their maturation.

questions.question: All of the following are true about tumors of the testis except:

options.B: Pure choriocarcinoma has an excellent prognosis
options.C: Seminomas only rarely occur in infants
options.D: Non-seminomatous germ-cell tumour metastasize using hematogenous route

questions.explanation: Pure choriocarcinoma is a rare, but aggressive, tumor and has a poor prognosis.It generally does not cause any testicular enlargement. It spreads rapidly via thebloodstream. This results in the frequent involvement of the lung and liver. However, puregerm-cell tumors (GCTs) are rare and about 60% of testicular GCTs are mixed tumors.Teratomas in children usually follow a benign course. But, in the postpubertal male, all teratomasare regarded as malignant because they are capable of metastatic behavior.

questions.question: What is the most common testicular tumor in infants?
questions.explanation: Yolk sac tumor is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age.Prepubertal teratoma is the second most common testicular tumor in infants and children.In adults, pure yolk sac tumor is rare. The yolk sac elements frequently occur in combination withembryonal carcinoma (as a mixed tumor).895

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presented with a painless testicular mass. Inguinal orchidectomy was doneand the gross and histological image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The gross specimen showing a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface that bulges aroundthe surrounding parenchyma is characteristic of a seminomatous germ-cell tumor or seminoma.The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus,with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance), delicate fibrous septa containing alymphocytic infiltrate.Fried egg appearance of SeminomaSeminoma is the most common type of GCT. The peak incidence is the 3rd decade and almostnever occurs in infants. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovariandysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, (regardless of KIT mutational status),OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).Option B: Yolk sac tumor is non-encapsulated with mucinous appearance. Schiller-Duval bodiesare characteristic. It is seen in children less than 3 years.Option C: Teratoma shows derivatives of more than one germ layer like cartilage, hair, sebaceousglands.Option D: Testicular lymphoma is a rare extranodal presentation of non-Hodgkin lymphomaTesticular biopsy is contraindicated in case of a suspicious testicular mass because it is associatedwith a risk of tumor cell spillage. High inguinal orchidectomy followed by histopathologicalevaluation is the preferred standard management. Fixative used for testicular biopsy is Bouin'sfluid.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presented with a testicular mass. Microscopic examination of theorchidectomy specimen was done. It showed highly anaplastic cells with hyperchromaticnuclei with prominent nucleoli growing in alveolar and tubular patterns. They stainedpositive for PLAP, cytokeratin, and CD30 and negative for KIT. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario of the germ-cell tumor is suggestive of embryonal carcinoma.896It is a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCTs) that occurs mostly in the 20 to 30 year agegroup. These tumors are more aggressive than seminomas. Embryonal carcinomas share somemarkers with seminomas such as OCT 3/4 and PLAP but differ by being positive for cytokeratinand CD30 and negative for KIT.Most patients present with a testicular mass, which can be painful due to rapid growth and maybe mistaken for torsion.Grossly, the tumor is often variegated, poorly demarcated at the margins, and punctuated by fociof hemorrhage or necrosis.Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillaryconvolutions; the neoplastic cells have an epithelial appearance, are large and anaplastic, andexhibit hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli.The below image is the histology of embryonal carcinoma showing anaplastic cells with largehyperchromatic nuclei.Embryonal carcinoma - HistopathologyEmbryonal carcinoma - Histopathology897Option A: Seminoma will have sheets of uniform cells with poor, demarcated lobules divided bydelicate fibrous septa infiltrated by lymphocytes. Seminomas are positive PLAP and KIT, butnegative for cytokeratin and CD30.Option C: Teratoma will show derivatives of more than one germ layer like cartilage, hairs,sebaceous glands in the histology.Option D: Yolk sac tumor affects children up to 3 yrs of age, will have elevated alpha-fetoprotein(AFP), and exhibit Schiller-Duval bodies on histology.

questions.question: 882A young man presented with a testicular mass and increased AFP levels. What is the likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: Marked elevation of serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels is produced by the yolk sactumor endodermal sinus tumor.It is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age (prepubertalyolk sac tumor). Postpubertal yolk sac tumors are associated with germ-cell neoplasia in situ andalmost always occur in mixed forms.Grossly, pure yolk sac tumors have a homogenous, mucinous appearance.The below image is of a yolk sac tumor showing lace-like architecture and Schiller-Duval bodies(Arrow) (a hallmark of YST), and hyaline-like globules. These structures consist of a mesodermalcore with central capillary as well as a visceral and parietal layer of cells (glomeruloid pattern)Yolk Sac Tumor - Histopathology898

questions.question: Which of the following is true about teratomas?

options.A: In post-pubertal males, all teratomas are considered benign.
options.B: All teratomas are benign even if they show immature elements.
options.C: All teratomas are considered malignant in post-pubertal males.
options.D: Orchidectomy is curative for testicular teratomas.

questions.explanation: In post-pubertal males, teratomas are considered malignant, regardless of the presence ofimmature elements.Teratomas are non-seminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCTS), which are characteristicallycomposed of more than one germ layer derivative (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm).Teratomas have complex histopathology and 2 variants may be seen:• Mature: Adult-type, well-differentiated cells or organoid structures•• Immature: Embryonal-type, undifferentiated cells or primitive neural elementsIn ovarian teratomas, immature elememts are needed to consider it malignant. However, thedegree of immaturity is clinically insignificant in testicular teratomas. In prepubertal children,testicular teratomas have a benign course. However, in postpubertal males, teratomas areconsidered malignant.The below image shows the histology of teratoma of the testis.899Teratoma -HistopathologyTeratoma -HistopathologyCartilage nodule(Mesoderm)Squamousepithelium(Ectoderm)Glandular elements(Endoderm)

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with hemoptysis and loss of weight. Chest radiograph showsmultiple canon-ball metastases. Physical examination revealed no palpable mass. The serumHCG level is raised, but no change in AFP and CEA levels. Biopsy from the lung lesion revealsthe following finding. What is the most likely primary tumor?
questions.explanation: From the given clinical scenario and image showing cytotrophoblasts and multinucleatedsyncytiotrophoblasts in a hemorrhagic background, the most likely primary tumor appears tobe choriocarcinoma.The syncytiotrophoblasts secrete -hCG, at levels that serve as important serological markers.Pure choriocarcinoma, although rare, is the most aggressive non-seminomatous germ cell tumor(NSGCT). It often does not cause any testicular enlargement; instead, it spreads rapidly via thebloodstream. This results in the frequent involvement of the lung(cannon-ball metastases) andliver and a poor prognosis.900CytotrophoblasticcellsChoriocarcinomaSyncytiotrophoblasticcells

questions.question: All of the following are true for spermatocytic tumors except:

options.A: It affects individuals generally younger than 35 years.
options.B: It does not have any extra-testicular sites of origin.
options.C: It is a slow-growing tumor that does not produce metastases.

questions.explanation: With a spermatocytic tumor, affected individuals are generally older than 65 years.A spermatocyte tumor (previously called spermatocytic seminoma) is a rare, slow-growing germcell tumor that is distinct from classical seminoma, both clinically and histologically.GCNIS: Germ-cell neoplasia in situPLAP: Placental alkaline phosphataseThe below image is the histology of spermatocytic tumor showing a population of small,medium-sized, and large cells and mucoid lakesCharacteristicsAgeAssociation with GCNIS, other GCT, cryptorchidismHistologySeminoma20-40 yrsPresentUniform looking cellsLymphocytes and granuloma PresenSpermatocytic tumor>65 yrsAbsentSmall, medium and large cellsLymphocytes and granuloma AbsentAbsentAbsentAbsenttIntracytoplasmic glycogenPresentPLAP reactivityPresentExtra testicular origin, metasPresenttasis901Spermatocytic Tumor - HistopathologySpermatocytic Tumor - HistopathologySmall cellsMedium cellsMucoid lakeLarge cells

questions.question: A 40-year-old man presents with gynecomastia. Ultrasonography reveals a 1 cm solid masswithin the body of the testis. His serum testosterone is 600 ng/dL and estradiol is 35 pg/mL.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Leydig cell tumor of the testis.It is the most common sex-cord stromal type of testicular neoplasm. It is mostly benign andinvariably unilateral. Most cases occur between 20 and 60 years of age. However, they can presentat any age.The most common presenting feature is testicular swelling or gynecomastia (~15% of cases). Inchildren, hormonal effects manifested primarily as sexual precocity, are the dominantfeatures. Tumors of Leydig cells may secrete androgens and estrogens, and even corticosteroids.Grossly it shows golden brown, homogeneous circumscribed nodules <5 cm in diameter.Histologically:902• large, round, or polygonal cells•⚫ round central nucleus and prominent nucleoli• abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm containing lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscinpigment•⚫ crystalloids of Reinke, rod-shaped eosinophilic cytoplasmic bodies are seen in about 25% of thetumorsOption A: Spermatocytic tumor mainly occurs in older adults as a slow-growing testicularmass. They are usually hormonally silentOption B: Sertoli cell tumor mostly presents as a painless testicular mass. They are usuallyhormonally silent. Hence, gynecomastia and precocious puberty are very rare.Option C: Granulosa cell tumor usually presents as a slow-growing and non-functioning testicularmass. Gynecomastia is rare. They usualy secrete estrogen.

questions.question: What is the most common testicular neoplasms in men older than 60 years?
questions.explanation: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is the most common testicular neoplasm in men older than 60 years.The most common types of testicular lymphomas in decreasing order of frequecy:• Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma• Burkitt lymphoma•⚫ Epstein-Barr virus positive extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma.Testicular lymphomas are aggressive tumors with a poor prognosis. They have a higher propensityfor CNS involvement.903

questions.question: In patients with testicular tumors, what lymph nodes are primarily involved?884
questions.explanation: Retroperitoneal para-aortic nodes are the first to be involved in the lymphatic spread of testiculartumors.Testicular tumors have a characteristic mode of spread:• Lymphatic spread is common to all forms of testicular tumors. Initially, it spreads toretroperitoneal para-aortic nodes, then spreads to the mediastinal and supraclavicular nodes.• Hematogenous spread is primarily to the lungs, but the liver, brain, and bones may also beinvolved.

questions.question: Laboratory testing of a 30-year-old man diagnosed with a testicular mass showed increasedlevels of alpha-fetoprotein. All of the following can be included in the differential, except:
questions.explanation: Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level is raised in all the above conditions except purechoriocarcinoma and pure seminoma.Choriocarcinomas have elevated levels of HCG, which can be readily demonstrated in thecytoplasm of syncytiotrophoblastic cells.AFP is a marker of hepatocellular cancer and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of testes,mainly yolk sac tumors.

questions.question: Which tumor responds best to radiation therapy?
questions.explanation: Seminomas are extremely radiosensitive tumors.The counterpart of seminoma, which arises in the ovary, is dysgerminoma.

questions.question: What is the most common malignant paratesticular tumor in children?
questions.explanation: The most common malignant paratesticular tumor in children is rhabdomyosarcoma.The paratesticular region is an extratesticular anatomical area, which includes the contents:•Spermatic cord,•• Testicular tunics,⚫ Epididymis••Vestigial remnants, such as the appendices epididymis and testis.The most common malignant paratesticular tumor in adults is liposarcoma.The most common benign paratesticular tumor is an adenomatoid tumor.The most common paratesticular mesenchymal tumor is a lipoma.904

questions.question: Which of the following is not used as a tumor marker for germ cell testicular tumors?885
questions.explanation: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is not used as a tumor marker for germ-cell testicular tumors. Itis an oncofetal antigen used as a tumor marker in adenocarcinoma of the colon, pancreas, lung,breast, and ovary.Markers of germ cell testicular tumors include alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), human chorionicgonadotropin, placental alkaline phosphatase, placental lactogen, and lactate dehydrogenase(LDH).

questions.question: A 61-year-old male patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia is planned for transurethralresection of the prostate. Which of the following is removed during the procedure?
questions.explanation: Benign prostatic hyperplasia originates almost exclusively in the transitional zone, hence it issurgically removed.Nodular hyperplasia or benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is the most common benign prostaticdisease in men above 50 years. It arises from the inner aspect of the prostate gland, i.e., thetransitional zone. It is characterized by benign, hyperplastic proliferation of prostatic stroma andepithelial elements, which is driven by dihydrotestosterone. This growth progressively compressesthe urethra resulting in urinary obstructive symptoms.The normal prostate contains several distinct regions, including a central zone (CZ), peripheralzone (PZ), transitional zone (TZ), and periurethral zone, as shown in the image below.Zones of prostateCentral zone.Transitional zoneOMARROWOW-Peripheralzone-FibromuscularzoneNote: Most carcinomas arise from the peripheral zone and maybe palpable during the digitalexamination of the rectum.

questions.question: An elderly man presenting with the features of urinary retention was thoroughly investigatedand diagnosed with prostate carcinoma. All of the following statements about the Gleasonsystem used for prognosis/survival of the patient are true except:

options.A: Grade group 1 represents the most well-differentiated tumors.
options.B: Tumors with Gleason scores 8 to 10 tend to be advanced cancers.
options.C: Gleason system correlates with pathologic stage and prognosis.
options.D: Gleason Score is reported from 1 to 10.

questions.explanation: The Gleason score is currently reported from 6-10.905WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score is the histopathological grading system, which correspondswith the clinical behavior of prostate cancer. It is one of the key methods used in confirmation ofthe diagnosis, prognostication, and staging of prostate cancer (adenocarcinoma).The Gleason grading system is primarily based on analyzing the architecture of the tumor cells inthe biopsy specimens obtained. The architecture, i.e., the Gleason Patterns are classified as:•Pattern 3: Well-formed glands⚫ Pattern 4: Poorly formed/Fused/Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands•• Pattern 5: Sheets of the tumor, individual cells, cords, and solid nests of cells, Comedo necrosis• Pattern 1 and 2 are no longer definedMost tumor specimens contain more than one pattern. Therefore, a numeric grade is assigned toboth the primary pattern and the next most frequent secondary pattern. The sum of thenumeric grades provides the Gleason score.• Scores 2-5 are no longer assigned.• Scores of 6 - 7 are potentially treatable cancers• Scores 8 - 10 are advanced cancers that are less likely to be cured.Based on the gleason score, they are classified into the following grade groups:• Grade group 1: score<=6•Grade group 2: 3+4=7• Grade group 3: 4+3=7• Grade group 4: score 8•Grade group 5: scores 9-10

questions.question: A 68-year-old man presented with hesitancy, incomplete voiding, and pelvic pain. On a digitalrectal examination, an irregularly enlarged prostate with a nodular surface was felt.Transrectal biopsy revealed poorly formed glands arranged in a cribriform pattern. Accordingto the modified Gleason score, how would you classify the pattern seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of prostate cancer and all cribriform patterns are now defined asGleason pattern 4 according to the 2014 WHO/ISUP grading consensus conference.The below image of prostate cancer with Gleason pattern 4 shows cribriform pattern906Highlights of 2014 WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score:1) Gleason Pattern:•Pattern 3- Well formed glands•⚫ Pattern 4- Poorly formed/Fused/Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands•• Pattern 5- Sheets of the tumor, individual cells, cords and solid nests of cells, Comedo necrosis• Pattern 1 and 2 are no longer defined2) Gleason Score:The current Gleason score ranges from 6–10. Scores 2-5 are no longer assigned.3) Grade group:• Grade group 1: score ≤6• Grade group 2: 3+4=7••Grade group 3: 4+3=7Grade group 4: score 8• Grade group 5: scores 9-10

questions.question: What is the normal upper limit of prostate-specific antigen value for a 75-year-old man?
questions.explanation: The upper-age-specific reference value of serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) in men of age70-79 is 6.5 ng/mL.PSA is a product of prostatic epithelium secreted in the semen. Measurement of serum PSA levelsis widely used to assist the diagnosis, prognosis, and management of prostate cancer. Older menhave a higher serum PSA level than younger men, so the normal range varies with age.907The serum PSA levels as a screening test for prostatic cancer has poor sensitivity and specificity.This is because various other factors such as trauma, infections, BPH, instrumentation/digitalexam of the prostate, and ejaculation can increase serum PSA levels. A value of ≥4 ng/mL usuallywarrants serial testing or further evaluation.In an effort to improve the sensitivity and specificity of serum PSA levels, many novel indices areused:.•Age-specific PSA reference rangesPSA velocity: Rate of change of PSA values with time. It is considered that PSA velocity of 0.75ng/mL per year measured at least 3 times over a period of 1.5 to 2 yrs is significant to diagnoseProstate cancer.• PSA density: Serum PSA/volume of the prostate gland•The ratio of free to bound serum PSAAgeUpper age-specific PSA(ng/mL)40-492.5yrs50-593.5yrs60-694.5yrs70-79yrs6.5

questions.question: A 68-year-old patient was diagnosed with prostate cancer. Hematogenous spread of thiscancer would occur predominantly to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Hematogenous spread of carcinoma prostrate occurs predominantly to the bones and are typicallyosteoblastic.The commonly involved bones in decreasing order of frequency:•• Lumbar spine• Proximal femur• Pelvis• Thoracic spine⚫ Ribs•908
